captions.text:
In the days when I was young and the internet 
was a new and bewildering concept we were still

fearfully hitting with mammoth bones to provoke 
a reaction, it was common practice for popular

movies to commission licensed video games as a 
form of cross-promotion. This practice has all

but ceased today, at least in the triple A sector, 
for two main reasons: developing games now takes

too long, and they can&#39;t be counted on to be ready 
to coincide with a movie launch, and secondly,

all but a very small number of such games were a 
load of old double-dipped dingo diapers. If you

want to adapt movies to games these days, you 
either take the Warriors route and aim for the

nostalgia crowd who don&#39;t care that both they and 
the property in question are about 40 years out

of relevance or you exclusively adapt IPs that 
we are apparently never, ever going to see the

fucking end of. Step forward, motherfucking Star 
Wars. And oh, isn&#39;t Star Wars Outlaws a match made

in Coruscant. An open world Ubisoft game set in 
Star Wars. We have officially reached the bland,

overproduced wank singularity. This is gonna 
be like when a storm cell meets another storm

cell in the upper atmosphere, and next morning, 
nobody has windows anymore. Except with wank.

I&#39;m going to spoil some late-game plot twists in 
the upcoming paragraph, so token spoiler warning,

but don&#39;t stress about it; this is like spoiling 
that it&#39;s not a good idea to train a hedgehog

to administer suppositories. Star Wars Outlaws 
tells the story of one specific Star Wars Outlaw,

Kay Vess, helmet-haired heroine with 
name straight from the random Star

Wars protagonist name generator who is a 
lowly street thief on a backwater world who

accidentally antagonizes a slick, villainous 
crime lord so wealthy and powerful he hires

someone to twirl his moustache for him, and 
of course, this is the exact same setup as

Assassin&#39;s Creed Mirage&#39;s protagonist because 
I swear Ubisoft these days just use a Mad Lib

instead of a design document and only ever 
change the fucking nouns. So we escape into

space to become a jobbing mercenary and later 
on get recruited by a slick, handsome, white

dude for a heist against the established slick, 
moustache-twirling villain. And not long after,

while zoning out during another copy-pasted 
stealth mission, I thought, &quot;Hey, hang on,

didn&#39;t the main villain in his opening monologue 
that felt like a Mad Libbed version of the

villain&#39;s opening monologue from Assassin&#39;s 
Creed Syndicate say something about growing

up with a brother? Oh, bollocks, I&#39;ve just 
predicted this game&#39;s entire plot, haven&#39;t I?&quot;

And indeed I had, but I don&#39;t feel smug; it&#39;s 
hardly the apotheosis of nuanced storytelling.

It&#39;s Star Wars, where the baddies all dress up 
like black sex toys and use the word &quot;scum&quot; like

it&#39;s a comma. &quot;But how does the game play, Yahtz?&quot; 
(Long pause; shuffling of chairs.) You. Fucking.

Know. How it plays. It plays like an Ubisoft open 
world game. As in all of them. If they&#39;d replaced

&quot;Empire&quot; with &quot;Templars&quot; and &quot;Rebels&quot; with 
&quot;Assassins,&quot; they probably could have called

it Assassin&#39;s Creed in Spaaaace, only with a lot 
less parkour &#39;cos the cities tend to be cramped

and lacking verticality, and the &quot;open world&quot; 
part of the open world Star Wars game promise

lies exclusively in the expansive plains of bugger 
all that some but not every visitable planet has

bolted onto the sides of the city areas for you to 
spend a few uneventful minutes motorbiking across.

You know what&#39;s really infuriating about Star 
Wars Outlaws is that I can&#39;t get particularly

infuriated at any specific part of it, and that 
just makes me even more infuriated. It&#39;s classic

Jiminy Cockthroat syndrome—spread across a million 
gameplay mechanics and focusing on none of them.

So of course you&#39;ve got bland stealth based on 
backstabbing unaware guards with microscopic

patrol routes who spend a lot of time taking 
inordinate interest in walls. Bland gun combat

about pew pewing away with an infinite ammo 
blaster until you can use your Red Dead

Redemption ripoff quickdraw headshot &quot;I&#39;m bored of 
having to put actual effort in&quot; power once you&#39;ve

built up enough of what is rather ironically 
termed &quot;adrenaline.&quot; It somewhat undermines

Kay&#39;s characterization as unconfident, waifish 
&quot;Oh, please be gentle, hostile universe-chan; I

am but a smol bean&quot; when she routinely knocks out 
armored men with a single punch and can trickshot

the testicles off a mayfly at twenty paces. Also, 
there&#39;s bland-ass corridor climbing, bland-anus

press-the-button puzzles, bland-bottom speeder 
racing, and bland-posterior space dogfighting;

looking for the core gameplay mechanic is 
like being at a speed dating event for middle

managers. None of them have anything particularly 
wrong with them, but none of them are sparking my

stovetop alight, either. I struggle to think 
of anything one could point to as the game&#39;s

unique selling point. Maybe Kay&#39;s little furry 
axolotl friend, but that&#39;s just something midway

between the bird friends in later Assassin&#39;s 
Creed games and the drones from Watch Dogs.

Its only really useful function besides contrived 
puzzle scenarios is to distract guards during

stealth, but you can also just whistle to lure 
them to the chest-high wall or tall grass,

and to add further bacon bits 
to this pointlessness potato,

you might as well not even bother with stealth 
in the first place &#39;cos direct combat isn&#39;t

hard, takes less time, and whether you lulled 
their henchmen to gentle sleepy time with scented

chloroform pillows or stabbed them all through 
the eye sockets with rolled-up photographs of

their murdered children is apparently a matter of 
indifference to the game&#39;s various crime lords,

who will just keep giving you chances to prove 
your loyalty even after you&#39;ve betrayed them so

many times you&#39;re basically using their spine 
as a knife tidy. Oh yeah, the faction system;

that could be a USP. Well, SP. Well, P, certainly. 
You do side jobs for the various gangs to improve

your standing with them, but the question I 
kept coming back to was &quot;why?&quot; Why should I

care how many stars are next to my name in Jabba 
the Hutt&#39;s crush diary? I thought about doing it

so they&#39;d let me wander around their territory 
unmolested so I could more easily complete certain

critical path missions, but then, shooting 
them all in the face proved a lot quicker.

There&#39;s a recurring mechanic where you go to 
a food vendor, watch an elaborate animation of

your dish being prepared, and then complete 
a prolonged sequence of quick-time events

to watch Kay and her pet Boglin eat it or stare 
longingly at it if you fail to hit the buttons,

and I wondered why this was happening unless 
there was a very bored designer on the team

who was a huge fan of both Monster Hunter and 
self-denial, but then I realized this was the

game&#39;s defining moment: massively overdesigned 
and completely pointless. &quot;One for Star Wars

fans&quot; would be the faint praise with which most 
reviewers would now damn Star Wars Outlaws;

there&#39;s even a very fan-servicey bit where Darth 
Vader shows up for all of five minutes to piss

all over the game&#39;s established villain and go, 
&quot;Hey, bet you wish you were playing something

with interesting characters like me in it,&quot; like 
it&#39;s a fucking Charles Atlas advert, but frankly,

I don&#39;t know even know what a &quot;Star Wars fan&quot; 
is anymore. No one could possibly be a fan of

absolutely everything with Star Wars on it 
now; it&#39;d be like being a fan of, I dunno,

pieces of paper. Come watch our announcement 
stream to hear about all the wonderful new pieces

of paper we&#39;re preparing for quarter four. 
One of them might have a willy drawn on it.
